photographer Robert Marcos is on a quest
to find a petroglyph in a remote and
dangerous location in the Californian
desert after a year of effort and
training we finally make it to this
patrick website petroglyphs are ancient
rock carvings but this one was not what
he expected initially I was heartbroken
because I was hoping for a wooly mammoth
or a water buffalo or a saber-toothed
cat it's not that old it's maybe 450
years old perhaps and it's crudely drawn
and it's obviously a ship my gut feeling
is it's a ship I knew it immediately I
saw a horse I saw a single mast astern
it's quite quite clearly a ship it's an
amazing new discovery it's a historical
record of a boat found in the middle of
the desert could this be evidence of the
lost ship
the petroglyph was verified by historian
Rey Ashley from the San Diego Maritime
Museum where they now keep a replica
that's not ancient the reason that
that's thought to be the case is because
the the rocks have a crust and that
crust is caused by a gas which exudes
from the rock mixing with algae on the
surface so gradually the image begins to
fade so given the relative brightness of
that image compared to the ones around
it the census is that is hundreds of
years old it's not modern grafitti
Ashley thinks the image is of the first
recorded Spanish ship to explore the
coast of California the San Salvador in
1542 if you look at the San Salvador
itself there's several things you see
you seem a sticking up which you can
kind of visualize here you can see these
vertical and horizontal portions here
that look a lot like the skids and when
whales on the ship you have this object
here it looks like an anchor if it is
then it's the oldest image of a recorded

of contact between native peoples and
Europeans as a record of first contact
it is priceless but others think it may
be evidence of a different ship
it's much more likely that the source of
the petroglyph was a ship that was
stranded in ancient lake hawea which is
only maybe 15 miles from the petroglyph
site versus 90 plus miles to the Spanish
ships coming in and out of San Diego
harbor if it is a Spanish ship in the
ancient lake what was it doing there
early Spanish maps indicate that the
Spanish believed that California was an
island and in order to encourage folks
to explore this possibility they would
distribute pearl collecting licenses to
incentivize people to go into this
region to collect black pearls which at
the time would have been more valuable
to gold my belief is that if there is a
lost ship it represents the loss

you think about this period that
conquistadors veil of discovery they

riches and fertile lands
